title: A Beginning Look at Photosynthesis
description: Students learn about plant response to light by setting up simple investigations in the classroom.

title: A Field View of Soil - Digging Around
description: Students discover that soil properties such as moisture and temperature can vary considerably across a single landscape.

title: A SneakPreview of Budburst
description: Students learn what to look for during budburst by observing variations in timing and appearance of leaves of different local plant species.

title: A. Flowchart for Carbon Cycle and Systems Introductory Materials
description: Use this flowchart to help you decide which Introductory Activities are appropriate for your classroom. For more information, see theCarbon Cycle Introduction eTraining.

title: A. How To Measure Trees
description: Students explore the relationship between circumference and diameter, learn that circumference is measured at 1.35 m from the tree base, and how to accurately measure trees in the field.

title: A. Site Selection
description: Select a Carbon Cycle Site. Determine if your site isSTANDARD(accessible area of at least 225m2of contiguous vegetation) orNON-STANDARD(an area with some vegetation and some human interference, i.e. a local park, city block, or the school area itself). *This protocol can be done with or without student involvement.B. Carbon Cycle Activity and Protocol Flow ChartsUse these clickable flowcharts to decide the best way to use the Carbon Cycle materials in your classroom.STANDARD Flow Chart (pdf)NON-STANDARD Flow Chart (pdf)

title: Accuracy Assesment Tutorial
description: Students learn how to evaluate the accuracy of a classification they perform in this tutorial.

title: Aerosols
description: Measure the aerosol optical thickness of the atmosphere (how much of the sun’s light is scattered or absorbed by particles suspended in the air). Students point a GLOBE sun photometer at the sun and record the largest voltage reading they obtain on a digital voltmeter connected to the photometer. Students observe sky conditions near the sun, perform the Cloud, Barometric Pressure and Relative Humidity Protocols, and measure current air temperature.

title: Alkalinity protocol
description: Students will measure the alkalinity of water using an alkalinity test kit.

title: An Alaskan Spring Mystery- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Students learn about the timing of spring budburst, develop multiple working hypotheses about why timing differs year to year, and test hypotheses using environmental data collected by GLOBE students in Alaska to come to a conclusion about the factors that most impact timing of budburst on paper birch trees. **This activity has an option to get students analyzing data in spreadsheets.

title: Arctic Bird Migration Monitoring protocol
description: Over the year, students observe when specified migratory bird species first arrive and count their numbers until few or none of them remain.

title: AUTOMATED WEATHER STATIONS
description: Automated Weather Stations (AWSs) can collect a variety of data for upload to GLOBE. They are also known as Personal Weather Stations (PWSs).

title: B. Data Entry
description: Share your Biomass and Carbon data with the GLOBE community. When you submit your data through GLOBE, the calculations to convert your raw data to biomass and carbon storage values will be completed for you.Data Analysis Supporting ProtocolsTree Biomass and Carbon Analysis (pdf)Students observe and understand patterns and trends in their tree field measurement data.Enhancement Materials:Carbon & Biomass Data Example (xls)Shrub&Sapling Biomass and Carbon Analysis (pdf)Students observe and understand patterns and trends in their shrub/sapling field measurement data.Enhancement Materials:Carbon & Biomass Data Example (xls)Herbaceous Biomass and Carbon Analysis (pdf)Students observe and understand patterns and trends in their herbaceous field measurement data.Determining Scale and Calculating Area (pdf)Use an aerial photo/map to scale your sample site carbon measurements to larger areas of similar vegetation.Carbon in Humans vs. Trees (pdf)Use a back-of-the-envelope calculation or spreadsheet equations to determine whether more carbon is stored in humans or trees.Enhancement Materials:Human Vs. Tree C Spreadsheet (xls)Net Primary Productivity (pdf)Understand the change in carbon storage over time by calculating Net Primary Productivity (NPP). *Needs multiple years of carbon data*Enhancement Materials:NPP Analysis Spreadsheet (xls)

title: B. Paperclip Simulation and Model- Introduction to Systems Thinking
description: Introduce students to systems thinking through a classroom simulation, and model a system using the '1-box model'.Enhancement Materials:Paper Clip Simulation Spreadsheet (xls)Online Model Link

title: Barometric Pressure
description: Students use an aneroid barometer to measure barometric pressure in support of the Aerosols and Water Vapor Protocols.

title: Biomass Accumulation Model Resources
description: Resources needed for running the Biomass Accumulation Model.

title: Biometry protocol
description: Students measure properties of vegetation and identify species in order to classify land cover using the MUC System and to provide supplemental information about their site.

title: Biosphere Investigation Instruments - Clinometer
description: Students construct and use the clinometer by following the directions and using the formula below. The clinometer also lends itself for additional hands-on teaching exercises of trigonometric principles

title: Biosphere Investigation Instruments - Compass
description: Students will use the compass to set up field sites that can be measured and returned to every year. In addition, the a compass is used to help orientate soil temperature and moisture sites, ensure that the door to the Atmosphere Instrument Shelter is facing away from the Equator, and in noting direction on all site maps.

title: Biosphere Investigation Instruments - Densiometer
description: A densiometer is an instrument used for taking measurements of canopy cover as part of the biometry measurements described in the Biometry Protocol. Students will follow these directions to construct and use the densiometer.

title: Biosphere Investigation Instruments - MUC
description: The GLOBE Program uses the Modified UNESCO Classification (MUC) System, a classification system which follows international standards and uses ecological terminology for the identification of specific land cover classes.

title: Biosphere Investigation Instruments - Tape Measure
description: Students use a tape measure often when taking measurements at Land Cover Sample Sites. It is critical that you use the tape measure in the correct manner. This portocol will help students become familiar with the tape measure.Tree HeightWith the Trees observation, users locate, measure the height of, and take a photograph of trees. Each GLOBE Observer tree height observation includes finding a tree or trees and taking tree height measurements using the smartphone cameras and the Trees tool built-in angle measuring techniques.

title: Biosphere Learning Activities
description: A summary of learning activities for the biosphere investigation area.

title: Bird Beak Accuracy Assessment
description: Students learn how to evaluate the accuracy of a classification they perform.

title: Building a Thermometer
description: Students construct simple thermometers to understand how and why liquid-in-glass thermometers work.

title: Bulk Density protocol
description: Students will measure the mass of a dry soil sample of known total volume including pore space to determine the density of the whole sample.

title: C. Carbon Cycle Adventure Story
description: Students follow a carbon atom through the carbon cycle using a choose your own adventure storybook.Enhancement Materials:Carbon Cycle Adventure Story Booklet (pdf)

title: C1. STANDARD Site Set-up
description: Students learn necessary skills and work in teams to set-up aSTANDARD SITE. Determine which vegetation types you will measure at your site. Use theProtocol Decision Tree (pdf)to help make this determination.

title: C2. NON-STANDARD Site Set-up
description: Students learn necessary skills and work in teams to set-up aNON-STANDARD SITE. Determine which vegetation types you will measure at your site. Use theProtocol Decision Tree (pdf)to help make this determination.

title: Calculating Relative Air Mass
description: Students are introduced to the concepts of solar elevation angle and relative air mass and learn how to determine relative air mass from measurements of solar elevation angle.

title: Carbon Cycle Protocol Decision Trees
description: Use these flowcharts to determine what vegetation types you will measure on your Carbon Cycle Sample Site. Note the differences between Standard and Non-Standard sites. If you are not sure what type of site you have, please see the Carbon Cycle Site Selection Protocol.

title: Change Detection Tutorial
description: Using MultiSpec, students compare two images of their GLOBE Study Site; one from the 1990's and one from the 2000's, to determine how the land cover has changed in that time span in this tutorial.

title: Climate and Latitude- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Students match GLOBE temperature data with its location given what they know about the relationship between latitude and seasonal temperature variations.

title: Cloud Watch
description: Students monitor clouds and weather to begin to understand the connections between the two.

title: Clouds Protocol
description: Observe and report which types of clouds are visible, how much of the sky is covered by clouds, and the opacity of clouds. Also report sky and surface conditions. Each observation is matched to satellite data of clouds taken about the same time and location. Cloud observations can be taken at any time! This Protocol is designed to be flexible and fit into your schedule, classifying, observing, and reporting cloud observations when it works for you. If you observe while a satellite is overhead, you can then receive an email from NASA comparing your observations to satellite data.NASA Support Page for GLOBE Clouds and Satellite ComparisonYour cloud observations help NASA to better understand the different types of clouds and the effects they have on our Earth’s climate. NASA matches cloud observations to corresponding satellite data. Satellites only see the top of the clouds while you see the bottom. By putting these two vantage points together we get a much more complete picture of clouds in the atmosphere.Find Satellite Overpass Times by accessing theNASA Cloud Satellite Portal.

title: Comparing Croatia Climates- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Through explorations of GLOBE atmosphere data from Croatia, students will build understanding of two climate zones. **This activity has an option to get students analyzing data in spreadsheets. The spreadsheet file (and answer key) can be found here: https://www.globe.gov/do-globe/globe-teachers-guide/atmosphere/data-exploration-learning-activities

title: Computer-aided Land Cover Mapping
description: Students use MultiSpec to perform unsupervised clustering of their Landsat TM image and then assign MUC classes to every cluster to create a land cover map.

title: Constructing a Model of ppbv of Surface Ozone
description: Students construct and compare cubes of different volumes to gain insight into small concentrations such as a part per million and a part per billion.

title: Contrail Chart
description: Students can use the GLOBE contrail chart to identify types of contrails.

title: D. Carbon Travels Game
description: Students play a dice game to follow a carbon atom as it travels through the Earth's carbon pools.

title: D1. STANDARD Tree Mapping
description: Students map the location of each tree in a STANDARD sample site. *Mapping only needs to be completed once per Carbon Cycle Site. *Can be done in conjunction with theSTANDARD Tree CircumferenceProtocol.

title: D2. NON-STANDARD Tree Mapping
description: Students map the location of each tree in a NON-STANDARD sample site. *Mapping only needs to be completed once per Carbon Cycle Site. *Can be done in conjunction withNON-STANDARD Tree CircumferenceProtocol.

title: Data at Altitude- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Through explorations of GLOBE temperature data from two nearby locations in Germany, students learn how temperature varies with altitude.

title: Davis Soil Moisture and Temperature Station Protocol
description: Students install soil moisture sensors and temperature probes and connect them to a Davis Soil Moisture and Temperature Station. Data are logged every 15 minutes and periodically students transfer these data to a computer and report them to GLOBE.

title: Davis Soil Moisture and Temperature Station protocol
description: Students install soil moisture sensors and temperature probes and connect them to a Davis Soil Moisture and Temperature Station. Data are logged every 15 minutes and periodically students transfer these data to a computer and report them to GLOBE.

title: Davis Weather Station Protocol
description: Students log atmosphere data using a Davis automated weather station. A weather station is setup to measure and record atmospheric measurements at 15 minute intervals. These measurements are transferred to your school's computer and then submitted to GLOBE via email data entry.

title: Digital Multi-Day Max-Min-Current Air and Soil Temperatures Protocol
description: Students use a digital multi-day maximum/minimum thermometer mounted in their instrument shelter to measure the maximum and minimum air and soil temperatures for up to six previous 24-hour periods.

title: Digital Multi-Day Max-Min-Current Air and Soil Temperatures protocol
description: Students will use a digital multi-day maximum/minimum thermometer mounted in their instrument shelter to measure the maximum and minimum air and soil temperatures for up to six previous 24-hour periods.

title: Digital Multi-Day Soil Temperatures protocol
description: Students will use a second digital multi-day maximum/minimum thermometer mounted in their instrument shelter to measure the maximum and minimum soil temperatures at 5 cm and 50 cm depths for up to six previous 24-hour periods.

title: Discovery Area Post-Protocol
description: Students use the satellite image of the GLOBE Study Site and their knowledge of remote sensing to decide where a new hospital should be located.

title: Dissolved Oxygen protocol
description: Students will measure dissolved oxygen in the water at their site using a dissolved oxygen test kit or probe

title: Do You Know Your MUC
description: Students classify land cover by visually examining their site as well as mapping and recording ground cover onto graph paper as they walk across their site. Students will use a GPS to locate the site in addition to photographing their site.

title: Draw Your Own Visualization
description: Students draw a visualization and learn about all the design choices involved and how these choices affect what is communicated by the visualization.

title: E. Getting To Know the Global Carbon Cycle
description: Students learn the basics of the carbon cycle through diagrams.Enhancement Mini-ActivitiesTurnover rate and residence time (pdf)How big is a petagram? (xls)Human Carbon Pool (xls)How Much Carbon is Stored in a Pencil? (xls)Field Learning ActivitiesActivities that teach important concepts and skills for understanding and conducting Carbon Protocols.

title: E1. STANDARD Tree Circumference
description: Measure circumference at breast height (CBH) for all mapped trees greater than 15 cm CBH on a STANDARD site. *Can be done in conjunction withTree Mapping,Shrub/Sapling, andHerbaceousSTANDARD Protocols.

title: E2. NON-STANDARD Tree Circumference
description: Measure circumference at breast height (CBH) for all mapped trees greater than 15 cm CBH on a NON-STANDARD site. *Can be done in conjunction withTree Mapping,Shrub/Sapling, andHerbaceousNON-STANDARD Protocols.

title: Earth Networks Schools Protocol
description: GLOBE schools participating in the Earth Networks Schools Program arrange for their data to be transferred automatically to GLOBE. A special GLOBE Atmosphere Study Site is defined for the school's Earth Networks weather station, and this activates an automatic transfer of their Earth Networks data to the GLOBE database.

title: Electrical Conductivity protocol
description: Students will measure electrical conductivity of water at freshwater hydrology sites.

title: Estimating Cloud Cover- A Simulation
description: Students practice estimating how much of the sky is covered by clouds.

title: F. Biomass Units
description: Students learn the concept of biomass and explore biomass data from biomes around the world.Enhancement Materials:Global Biomes Movie (m4v)Biomass Units Example (xls)

title: F1. STANDARD Shrub&Sapling
description: Measure shrub and sapling average height and percent cover on a STANDARD site. *Can be done in conjunction withTreeandHerbaceousSTANDARD Protocols.

title: F2. NON- STANDARD Shrub&Sapling
description: Measure shrub and sapling average height and percent cover on a NON-STANDARD site. *Can be done in conjunction withTreeandHerbaceousNON-STANDARD Protocols.

title: Fire Fuel protocol
description: Students take additional measurements of fire fuel at Land Cover Sample Sites.

title: First Look At Phenology
description: Students observe and classify local plants based on their patterns of change other than growth.

title: Freshwater Macroinvertebrates Protocol
description: Students will collect, identify, and count macroinvertebrates at freshwater hydrology sites.

title: From Mud Pies to Bricks
description: Students make mud pies by adding water to the various soil components, letting them dry and observing the pie's characteristics.

title: Frost Tube Protocol
description:
Students will construct a Frost Tube that is inserted into a hole in undisturbed and uncompacted soil. During the cold months, students measure the depth at which water in the Frost Tube has frozen, indicating that the surrounding soil has also frozen.

Watch theFrost Tube Training Video.

title: G. Percent Cover
description: Students practice the skill of estimating percent cover.

title: G1. STANDARD Herbaceous
description: Collect a random sample of herbaceous vegetation on a STANDARD SITE, and dry it in paper bags or a drying oven to measure biomass. *Can be done in conjunction withTreeandShrub/SaplingSTANDARD Protocols.

title: G2. NON-STANDARD Herbaceous
description: Collect a random sample of herbaceous vegetation on a NON-STANDARD SITE, and dry it in paper bags or a drying oven to measure biomass. *Can be done in conjunction withTreeandShrub/SaplingNON-STANDARD Protocols.

title: Getting to Know Your Satellite Imagery and GLOBE Study Site
description: Students use the satellite image of their GLOBE Study Site to become familiar with the different types of land cover in their area.

title: Global Connections- Earth systems at the Global Scale GC1- Your Regional to Global Connection
description: Using global scale maps of winds and ocean currents students predict what region(s) in other parts of the world might be affected by their region.

title: Global Connections- Earth systems at the Global Scale GC2- Components of the Earth system Working Together
description: Using data about the components of the Earth system at the global scale, students discuss how the components interact to form the Earth system as a whole and use the water cycle to explore this in more detail.

title: Global Patterns in Green-up and Green-down
description:
Students will analyze visualizations and
graphs that show the annual cycle of plant
growth and decline.

title: GPS - Relative and Absolute Directions Learning Activity
description: A set of activities to introduce students to latitude, longitude, coordinates and relative and absolute directions. A GPS receiver is not needed.

title: Green-Down protocol
description: Students will use a GLOBE Plant Color Guide to monitor the change in color of selected leaves of trees, shrubs or grasses.

title: Green-Down Video
description: My students recorded a video explaining their Green-Down measurements this fall. It was a great way for them to review why we make these observations and share them with GLOBE.

title: Green-up Cards
description: Students participate in a preparatory activity that will help them identify green-up progression in their local plants and this activity also introduces the idea of spatial scale related to plant observations.

title: Green-Up protocol
description: Students will monitor the budburst and growth of leaves of selected trees, shrubs or grasses.

title: H. Allometry
description: Students measure their height, arm span, and foot length to show how living organism’s parts are related to the whole. Students use this concept to understand how circumference of trees can be used to estimate biomass.Enhancement Materials:Allometry Example (xls)Modeling ActivitiesComputer models (at varying levels of complexity) predict the change in biomass and carbon storage or size of carbon pools and fluxes over time, and give students the opportunity to use an important scientific tool.

title: HOBO Data Logger Protocol
description: Students will use four temperature probes and a data logger to measure air temperature and soil temperatures at depths of 5 cm, 10 cm, and 50 cm every 15 minutes.

title: How Do Seasonal Temperature Patterns Vary Among Different Regions of the World
description: Students use GLOBE visualizations to display student data on maps and to learn about seasonal changes in regional and global temperature patterns.

title: How to Share Davis Weather Station Data with GLOBE (New way)
description: Share your Davis Weather Station data with GLOBE via this simple 2 step process. (Updated 2023).

title: How to stop sharing Davis data with GLOBE via the old way.pdf
description: If you're switching to the "new way" to send your Davis data to GLOBE - be sure to stop sharing via the "old way". This guide walks you through the steps to avoid sending duplicate data to GLOBE. (Updated for 2023)

title: Hydrosphere Learning Activities
description: Introduction document to the Hydrosphere Investigation Area Learning Activities.

title: Hydrosphere Protocols
description: Hydrosphere protocols introduction document.

title: I. Biomass Accumulation Model
description: Students learn to use a simple computer model to predict biomass, and carbon storage over time for any geographical biome. Can be done as a stand-alone activity or as a follow-up to conducting Carbon Cycle field measurements.Model Materials:Link to Online Computer ModelVideo TutorialExample Data Sheet (xls)Biome Map

title: Infiltration protocol
description: Students will use a dual ring infiltrometer that they can construct from large food container cans to measure the rate at which water soaks into the soil during a roughly 45-minute period.

title: Instrument Construction Instructions for Making a Secchi Disk and Transparency Tube to Measure Water Transparency
description: Students will construct a transparency tube to measure water transparency.

title: Instrument Construction Instructions for Making a Secchi Disk to Measure Water Transparency
description: Students will construct a secchi disk to measure water transparency.

title: Instrument Shelter Construction Protocol
description: Instructions for building an atmosphere instrument shelter.

title: Investigating Leaf Pigments
description: Students learn about plant pigmentation and photosynthesis while conducting simple investigations to demonstrate the presence of pigments other than chlorophyll in leaves.

title: Iowa's Highs and Lows- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Students interpret a frequency distribution of GLOBE temperature data to decide whether statements about the weather are accurate, citing the parts of the graph they used as the basis of their decision.

title: J. Simple Global Carbon Cycle Model Teacher Guide
description: Students use the global carbon cycle diagram to make pencil and paper calculations of changes to carbon pools after a few years. They then explore a computer model to look at changes in carbon pools and fluxes over hundreds of years.Model Materials:Link to Online Computer Model

title: Just Passing Through
description: Students are introduced to the basic concepts of how water passes through soil in an activity which illustrates the scientific method. More advanced students investigate the effects of soil characteristics on water infiltration and the chemistry of water that has passed through soil

title: Just Passing Through (Beginner Version)
description: Beginning students are introduced to the basic concepts of how water passes through soil in an activity which illustrates the scientific method. More advanced students investigate the effects of soil characteristics on water infiltration and the chemistry of water that has passed through soil

title: K. Global Carbon Cycle Model with Feedbacks Teacher Guide
description: This model builds on the Simple Carbon Cycle Model by including feedbacks in the global carbon cycle that modify the movement of carbon into and out of the atmosphere.Model Materials:Link to Online Computer ModelPlant-A-Plant Classroom ExperimentsHands-on cultivation experiments for the classroom, with options for structured, guided, or open levels of inquiry.Plant-A-PlantTeacher Guide (pdf)Materials List (xls)What Do Plants Need to Grow? (pdf)Seed Germination Lab Guide (pdf)Structured Experiment: Light (pdf)Basic Experiments (Guided Inquiry)Temperature (pdf)CO2Decrease (pdf)Water (pdf)Mineral Nutrients (pdf)Advanced Experiments (Open Inquiry)Photosynthesis (pdf)CO2Increase (pdf)Soil Respiration (pdf)Mineral Nutrients II (pdf)

title: Land Cover Change Detection
description: Using MultiSpec, students compare two images of their GLOBE Study Site; one from the 1990's and one from the 2000's, to determine how the land cover has changed in that time span.

title: Land Cover Sample Site protocol
description: Students locate, photograph, and determine the MUC class for 90 m x 90 m areas of homogeneous land cover.

title: Land, Water, and Air
description: Students measure temperature change in soil, water and air as they are exposed to the heating action of the sun.

title: Leaf Classification
description: Students make a collection of leaves and then discover how a hierarchical classification system is developed by sorting and organizing their leaves according to a set of labels and rules which they specify.

title: Learning to Use Visualizations - An Example with Elevation and Temperature
description: Students use visualizations to explore the relation between elevation and temperature and begin learning how to make important patterns evident in visualizations.

title: Lilac Phenology Protocol
description: Students record the five phenophases of either common or clonal lilac plants.

title: Local Connections- earth systems in the Local Study Site LC1- Connecting the Parts of the Study Site
description: Students visit the study site, observe the different components of the Earth system and predict how they are connected to and affect each other.

title: Local Connections- earth systems in the Local Study Site LC2- Representing the Study Site in a Diagram
description: Students, either individually or in small groups, use their knowledge of their study site develop a diagram that illustrates the most important connections between the different components of the Earth system.

title: Local Connections- earth systems in the Local Study Site LC3- Using Graphs to Show Connections
description: Students use GLOBE student data to explore, understand, and communicate the connections between the components of the Earth system exist at the study site they are investigating.

title: Local Connections- earth systems in the Local Study Site LC4- Diagramming the Study Site for Others
description: Students compare and contrast the diagrams of their study site developed by individuals or small groups, and develop a class diagram of their study site that best communicates the most important connections between the components of the Earth system that exist there.

title: Local Connections- earth systems in the Local Study Site LC5- Comparing the Study Site to One in Another Region
description: Students compare and contrast diagram of their study site with a diagram developed for a region that is biogeographically different than their own.

title: Making a Climograph- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Students learn how to construct, read, and analyze climographs and understand how climate differs from weather.

title: Making a Contour Map
description: Students construct one or more contour maps using GLOBE data.

title: Making a Sundial
description: Students study the movement of the sun during the day by making quantitative observations of the direction and length of the shadow cast by a stick (known as a solar gnomon).

title: Manual Land Cover Mapping
description: Students outline and label different areas of land cover as seen on their Landsat TM image to create a land cover map.

title: Manual Mapping- A Tutorial for the Beverly, MA, Image
description: Students outline and label different areas of land cover as seen on their Landsat TM image to create a land cover map in this tutorial.

title: Maximum, Minimum, and Current Temperature
description: Measure the current air temperature when an instrument shelter is not available. Current air temperature is measured using a thermometer held in the open air but in the shade for at least 3 minutes.

title: Model a Catchment Basin
description: Students will make a 3-dimensional model of a catchment basin to understand how water moves through the basin and explore how water is affected when there are changes in the basin.

title: Modeling Your Water Balance
description: Students will model the changes in soil water storage over a year.

title: Monsoons and Health- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Students learn about the relationship between three infectious diseases and rainfall in the country of Benin.

title: Mosquito Protocol
description:
Please visit theGLOBE Observer websiteto view
supporting resources and download the Mosquito Habitat Mapper Tutorial.

title: MUC Field Guide
description: A Key to Land Cover Classification

title: Nitrate Protocol
description: Students will measure the nitrate-nitrogen content of water using a nitrate test kit.

title: NON-STANDARD Carbon Cycle Activity and Protocol Flowchart
description: Use this clickable flowchart to help you decide the best way to use the GLOBE Carbon Cycle materials in your classroom. (Linked protocols are for a Non-Standard Site)

title: Observing Cloud Type
description: GLOBE Data Entry AppGLOBE Observer AppCloud Protocol eTrainingContrail Formation TutorialCloud Cover PracticeCloud Type Practice

title: Observing Visibility and Sky Color
description: Students observe sky color and learn to associate color with the presence or absence of aerosols.

title: Observing, Describing, and Identifying Clouds
description: Students begin to learn cloud types and their names.

title: Odyssey of the Eyes Advanced Level
description: To help students understand the connection between remote sensing technology, computer imagery and land cover assessment and to demonstrate how a satellite sensor relates information to a computer

title: Odyssey of the Eyes Beginning Level
description: To familiarize students with the importance of perspective and introduce students to various scales of remotely sensed data.

title: Odyssey of the Eyes Intermediate Level
description: To familiarize students with the concept of modeling as it is related to remote sensing and to the process of digitizing images.

title: Optional Salinity Titration Protocol
description: Students will measure the salinity of saltwater using a salinity titration kit.

title: Ozone Measurement Stand and Wind Direction Instrument Construction Protocol
description: Instructions for making an ozone measurement station and wind direction instrument.

title: Particle Size Distribution protocol
description: Students will suspend a known mass of dry soil in water and measure the specific gravity of the suspension after sand and then silt has settled out of the suspension to determine the amount of each soil particle size group in the sample

title: pH Protocol
description: Students will measure the pH of water using either pH paper or a pH meter.

title: Phenological Gardens
description: Students plant a garden and observe the flowering and leaf development stages of specified plants throughout the year.

title: Practicing Your protocols
description: In the classroom, students practice using the instruments or kits for protocols, exploring the range of measurements and sources of variation and error.

title: Precipitation
description: To determine the amount of moisture input to the local environment by measuring rain and snowfall and to measure the pH of precipitation.

title: Rainfall in the GLOBE Africa Region- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Through explorations of GLOBE rain depth data from Africa, students learn about seasonal patterns in locations affected by monsoons. **This activity has an option to get students analyzing data in spreadsheets. The spreadsheet file (and answer key) can be found here: https://www.globe.gov/do-globe/globe-teachers-guide/atmosphere/data-exploration-learning-activities

title: RainWise Weather Station Protocol
description: Students log atmosphere data using a RainWise automated weather station. A weather station is setup to measure and record atmospheric measurements at 15 minute intervals. These measurements are transferred to your school's computer and then submitted to GLOBE via email data entry.

title: Regional Connections- earth systems at a Regional Level RC1- Defining Regional Boundaries
description: Students broaden their understanding of the Earth system by expanding their view of the Earth system from the local site to a regional system by identifying the boundaries of a regional Earth system.

title: Regional Connections- earth systems at a Regional Level RC2- Effects of Inputs and Outputs on a Region
description: Students examine the inputs and outputs of a regional scale Earth system and predict what would happen to that system if any of those inputs or outputs were changed.

title: Relative Humidity Protocol
description: Students measure the relative humidity using either a digital hygrometer or a sling psychrometer.

title: Ruby Throated Hummingbird(RTHU) Protocol
description: Students will observe the arrival and departure of Ruby-throated Hummingbirds, monitor hummingbird visits to flowers and feeders, and observe nesting behavior.

title: S1- What Can We Learn About Our Seasons
description: Students develop a qualitative understanding of the characteristics and patterns of seasons and highlight the relationship of seasons to physical, biological and cultural markers.

title: S2-What Are Some Factors That Affect Seasonal Patterns
description: Students use GLOBE data and graphing tools to compare the influence of latitude, elevation, and geography on seasonal patterns.

title: S3-How Do Seasonal Temperature Patterns Vary Among Different Regions of the World
description: Students use GLOBE visualizations to display student data on maps and to learn about seasonal changes in regional and global temperature patterns.

title: S4- Modeling the Reasons for Seasonal Change
description: Students use color visualizations and a 3-D paper model of the Earth to explore the causes of seasons, with a focus on Earth's tilt and its spherical shape.

title: S5- Seasonal Change on Land and Water
description: Students use visualizations to compare the effects of incoming solar energy in the two hemispheres, furthering their understanding of seasonal change and climatic effects of land and water.

title: Salinity Protocol
description: Students will measure the salinity of a salty or brackish water sample using a hydrometer and thermometer.

title: Sample Site Selection and Set-Up
description: Students select a 90 m x 90 m homogeneous site to carry out the Land Cover Sample Site Protocol and set-up the site to take the appropriate measurements.

title: Seaweed Reproductive Phenology protocol
description: Students collect specified seaweed species and observe the reproductive phenological phases of the seaweed.

title: Selecting, Exposing, and Defining a Soil Characterization Site
description: Students will use a technique chosen by their teacher to expose a soil profile for characterization.

title: Site Seeing Beginning Level
description: To help students determine that a system's boundaries are based upon the question(s) a scientist wants to answer.

title: Site Seeing Intermediate Level
description: To investigate the idea that every dynamic system has energy and matter in several different forms. Inputs and outputs will vary depending upon the physical components of the site, the plant and animal life, the determined boundaries or scale of the study and the season.

title: Site Selection Protocols
description: Instructions are provided on how to select, describe and map a hydrosphere study site.

title: SMAP Block Pattern Soil Moisture Protocol
description: Students will obtain in situ measurements of soil moisture that are consistent with soil moisture measurements from the Soil Moisture Active Passive (SMAP) satellite.

title: Snow Board Construction Protocol
description: Instructions for making a snow board for measuring solid precipitation.

title: Soil and My Backyard
description: Students collect, describe and compare soils from their own backyards.

title: Soil Characterization protocol
description: Students will identify horizons in a soil profile, observe the structure, color, consistence, texture, and the presence of rocks, roots, and carbonates of each horizon, and take samples for use in laboratory characterization protocols.

title: Soil Fertility protocol
description: Students will use a GLOBE Soil Fertility Kit to prepare samples and determine whether nitrate, phosphate, and potassium are absent from a soil sample or present in low, medium or high concentrations.

title: Soil Makers
description: Students will understand the geologic phenomena of weathering and erosion. These processes, along with deposition, shape our landforms and contribute to the development of parent material in the soil formation process.

title: Soil Moisture - Gravimetric protocol
description: Students will measure soil water content by comparing the wet and dry masses of samples.

title: Soil Moisture Sensor protocol
description: Students will develop a calibration curve and use it to determine soil water content at depths of 10 cm, 30 cm, 60 cm, and 90 cm from meter readings of four soil moisture sensor blocks.

title: Soil Particle Density protocol
description: Students will measure the volume of a known mass of dry soil particles and calculate the density of the particle portion only of a soil sample.

title: Soil pH protocol
description: Students will prepare a one-to-one mixture of dry soil and distilled water and then measure the pH of the liquid left after most of the soil has settled to the bottom of the mixture.

title: Soil Temperature protocol
description: Students will measure near-surface soil temperature frequently near local solar noon and seasonally throughout two diurnal cycles.

title: Soil-The Great Decomposer
description: Students simulate environmental conditions in order to determine the key factors that affect the decomposition of organic material in soil.

title: Soils as Sponges- How Much Water Does Soil Hold
description: Students explore soil moisture by weighing and drying sponges and then they explore their soil samples in the same way.

title: STANDARD SITE Carbon Cycle Activity and Protocol Flow Chart
description: Use this clickable flowchart to help you decide the best way to use the GLOBE Carbon Cycle materials in your classroom. (Protocol links are for a Standard Site)

title: Studying The Instrument Shelter
description: Students explore how the placement and design of instrument shelters can influence temperature measurements taken from thermometers located inside them.

title: Surface Ozone Protocol
description: Students expose a chemically sensitive strip to the air for an hour and determine the amount of ozone present using an ozone strip reader.

title: Surface Temperature Protocol
description: Students use an infrared thermometer (IRT) to measure the temperature of Earth's surface.

title: SystemsAndModelsIntroduction.pdf
description: Systems and Modeling terms and concepts

title: Temperature and Precipitation as Limiting Factors in Ecosystems
description:
Students correlate graphs of vegetation vigor with those of temperature and precipitation
data for four diverse ecosystems to determine which climatic factor is limiting growth.

title: The Data Game
description: Teams of students play a game in which they gather data and distort the values of certain measurements. They then estimate the values of the measurements taken by other teams and try to detect their errors.

title: The pH Game
description: Students will create mixtures of water samples, soil samples, plants and other natural materials to better understand the importance of pH levels.

title: Turnover Rate & Residence Time Mini Activity (pdf)
description: Students explore the concepts of turnover rate and residence time with the Global Carbon Cycle Diagram.

title: Using GLOBE Data to Analyze Land Cover
description: Students find another GLOBE school that reported the same MUC class and systematically compare the other GLOBE measurements that they each reported.

title: Water Detectives
description: Students will investigate how they use their senses for observation and why we use instruments to collect data.

title: Water Sampling
description: Students will first measure water transparency at their undisturbed study site using a transparency tube or Secchi disk.

title: Water Temperature Protocol
description: Students will measure the temperature of water.

title: Water Transparency Protocol
description: Students will first measure water transparency at their undisturbed study site using a transparency tube or Secchi disk.

title: Water Vapor Protocol
description: Students use a near-infrared sun photometer to measure the amount of sunlight reaching the ground at wavelengths that are correlated to water vapor.

title: Water Walk
description: Students become acquainted with their Hydrosphere Study Site.

title: Weather Tourists- A GLOBE Data Exploration
description: Students build geography skills while learning how to find data using the GLOBE Data Visualization tool, sharing what they have learned in a tourism poster for a GLOBE school location.

title: WeatherHawk Weather Station Protocol
description: Students log atmosphere data using a WeatherHawk automated weather station. A weather station is setup to measure and record atmospheric measurements at 15 minute intervals. These measurements are transferred to your school's computer and then submitted to GLOBE via email data entry.

title: What Are Some Factors That Affect Seasonal Patterns
description: Students use GLOBE data and graphing tools to compare the influence of latitude, elevation, and geography on seasonal patterns.

title: What is the Carbon Cycle Project
description: An overview of the major components of the Carbon Cycle Project, including learning goals and objectives. Also includes project authorship and citation information.Teacher PreparationCarbon Cycle eTrainingsCarbon Cycle Introduction, Standard Site Field Protocols, Non-Standard Site Field Protocols, Carbon Cycle Modeling.Scientific Inquiry and Research in the ClassroomIntroduction to the Global Carbon CycleSystems and Models IntroductionNGSS and Standards Correlation MatrixCurriculum Framing QuestionsExamples of Essential, Unit and Content questions for GLOBE Carbon CycleTeacher templatesGeneral teaching templates that can be used for formative assessment. Frayer Model, KWL's, etc.Scientific Process Teacher GuidesPose Research Questions (pdf)Develop Investigation Plan (pdf)Identify New Research Questions (pdf)AssessmentField Wrap-up Questions (pdf)Field Assessment Questions (pdf)Excel Sheet Data Entry and Biomass Analysis TemplatesEntering data into theGLOBE databasealso performs these functionalities.Tree Biomass Analysis Template (xls)Standard Site Shrub Biomass Analysis Template (xls)Non- Standard Site Shrub Biomass Analysis Template (xls)

title: Why Do We Study Soil
description: An activity which highlights the importance of learning about the soils on Earth. In this activity students explore some of the many uses of soils, learn the five soil-forming factors, and gain a better understanding of how little of Earth's surface is covered in soil.
